desc: To select elements with a specific class, write a period (.) character, followed by the name of the class.

examples.html: Awesome Styles
<nav id='menu'>Click Nav</nav>

desc: To select elements with a specific id, write a hash (#) character, followed by the name of the id.

desc: The element selector selects all elements with the specified tag name
To style several elements with the same style, separate each element name with a comma.

desc: To select elements inside elements
A descendant selector in CSS is any selector with white space between two selectors without a combinator

examples.html:
• List Item 1
  • List Item 2

desc: Elements that are directly a child of the specified parent, are selected.
A child combinator in CSS is the 'greater than' symbol
It is called as direct descendent selector/child selector

examples.html:
• Color red
  • Color red
    1. Color will not be red

<label class='inputLabel'>Not Selected</label>
<input class='inputBox' type='text'>
<label class='inputLabel'>Selected</label>
<label class='inputLabel'>Not Selected</label>

desc: Elements that is placed immediately after the first specified element will be selected.
The plus sign (+) is the adjacent sibling combinator
This selector matches occurrences of element2 that are preceded by element1 at the same hierarchy level
This is general sibling combinator (~) in CSS

examples.html:
<label class='inputLabel'>Not Selected</label>
<input class='inputBox' type='text'>
<label class='inputLabel'>Selected</label>
<label class='inputLabel'>Selected</label>

desc: It selects all the elements irrespective of the hierarchy level

examples.desc: All the elements inside the container selector will be affected.

desc: This selector selects all the elements with the specified attribute

examples.html:
<input type='text' value='Not Selected'>
<input required type='text' value='Selected'>

desc: This selector is used to select elements with the specified attribute and exact value

examples.example: input[type='text']{ border: 2px solid white; color: green;}
examples.html:
<input type='number' value='100'>
<input type='text' value='Selected'>

desc: This selector is used to select elements with an attribute value containing a specified word
It will select the Elements with the attribute value that starts with the specified value in a dash-separated list

desc: The :active selector is used to select and style the active element
A element becomes active when you click on it.
It's usually only seen for a split second, and provides visual feedback that the element was indeed clicked

examples.html: Selected Selected Selected Not Selected
examples.desc: It only works on <a> elements with the href attribute.

desc: The :link selector is used to target all the unvisited anchor <a> elements on a page

examples.html: Selected
examples.desc: It can only change color, background-color, outline-color, border-color properties.

desc: This selector is used to target all the visited anchor <a> elements on a page
It only works on <a> elements
It is used to select elements, when the mouse/cursor is over them.

examples.html: CSS Selectors
examples.desc: It works on all the elements

desc: It is used to select input elements of type checkbox and radio, only when they are in selected state.

examples.html: <input type='checkbox' checked>Check Me

<select>
		<option>Item 1</option>
		<option>Item 2</option>
		<option>Item 3</option>
		<option>Item 4</option>
</select>

desc: The :default selector is used to style default selected value in the input element
It only affects <button> <input type='checked'> <input type='radio'> <option> tags.

examples.html:
<input type='radio' name='question' checked value='yes'>Yes
<input type='radio' name='question' value='no'>No

examples.example: input[type='text']:disabled{ color: grey; border: 2px dotted grey;}
examples.html:
<input type='text' disabled value='Selected'>
<input type='text' disabled='disabled' value='Selected'>
<input type='text' disabled='' value='Selected'>

desc: This selector target the elements which has disabled attribute.
It affects <button>, <input>, <textarea>, <optgroup>, <option> and <fieldset> tags
This selector targets the elements which are not disabled
It affects <input>, <select>, <textarea>, <button>, <optgroup>, <option> and <fieldset>

examples.example: input:enabled + label{ font-style: italic; color: dodgerblue;}
examples.html:
<input type='checkbox' id='genderM'>
<label for='genderM'>Male</label>
<input type='checkbox' id='genderF' disabled>
<label for='genderF'>Female</label

Selected
Selected
Not Selected

desc: The :focus pseudo class in CSS is used for styling an element that is currently targeted by the keyboard event or focused by mouse.
It is affected by <a>, <button>, <input>, and <textareas> tags and Elements with contenteditable and tabindex attribute

examples.html:
<input type='text' value='Selected'>
<input type='text' value='Not Selected' required>

desc: This selector target the input elements which are not set with the required attribute
It affects <input>, <select>, <textarea> tags

examples.html: <input id='name' type='text' value='red' required>

desc: This selector targets the input elements which has required attribute.
It affects <input>, <select>, <textarea> tags

examples.html: <input type='text' pattern='^[a-z].*' value='123Start' placeholder='only lowercase letters'>

desc: The :invalid selector allows you to select input elements that do not contain valid content.
The input elements with min, max, required, pattern attributes, email field without a legal email and number field with non numeric values will be affected.

examples.html: <input type='number' min='0' max='100' placeholder='number between 0 to 100'>

desc: The :valid selector allows you to select input elements that contain valid content.
It affects input elements

examples.html: <input type='number' min='0' max='100' value='50'>

desc: It selects the input elements whose value is within the range specified by min and max attribute

examples.html: <input type='number' min='0' max='100' value='220'>

desc: It selects the input elements whose value is outside the specified range.
It is affected by min and max attribute of the input elements.

desc: It selects input elements with readonly attribute and all other elements which are not affected by contenteditable and disabled attribute

examples.html:
Read Write
Read Only

desc: It selects input elements with disabled attribute and without readonly attribute
It also affects contenteditable elements
It selects input elemets that are in indeterminate state
It affects <input type='checkbox'>, <input type='radio'> and <progress> tags
Checkbox can be set to indeterminate state only from javascript.

examples.html: <input type='checkbox' id='checkBox'> Checkbox State
<input class='textBox' type='text' placeholder='Search'>

desc: This selector is used to style the placeholder text.
It affects input elements with placeholder attribute
The :placeholder-shown is for selecting the input itself when it's placeholder text is being shown

examples.html: <input type='text' placeholder='Search'>
